fr:title.text: Composite morphisms in the internal language of a category

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Composite morphisms in the internal language of a category

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathcal {C} be a regular category. f\colon A\to C is the composite of g\colon A\to B and h\colon B\to C iff \mathcal {C} satisfies x\colon A|\top \vdash f(x) = h(g(x)) in its internal language.

Suppose that f = hg. Then {\mathopen {}\llbracket h(g(x))\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{\mathcal {C}} = {\mathopen {}\llbracket h\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{\mathcal {C}} \circ {\mathopen {}\llbracket g\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{\mathcal {C}} \circ \mathsf {id}_{A} = hg and {\mathopen {}\llbracket f(x)\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{\mathcal {C}} = {\mathopen {}\llbracket f\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{\mathcal {C}} \circ \mathsf {id}_{A} = f. Thus, the equalizer of {\mathopen {}\llbracket f(x)\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{\mathcal {C}} and {\mathopen {}\llbracket h(g(x))\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{\mathcal {C}} is the terminal object, and the result follows immediately.

Suppose the converse. Then the identity morphism \mathsf {id}_{A} equalizes {\mathopen {}\llbracket f(x)\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{\mathcal {C}} and {\mathopen {}\llbracket h(g(x))\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{\mathcal {C}}. Thus, it follows that f = hg.

Let \mathcal {C} be a category. The internal language of \mathcal {C} consists of the signature \Sigma whose sorts are the objects of \mathcal {C}, function symbols are the morphisms of \mathcal {C}, and relation symbols are the subobjects in \mathcal {C}.

We write \mathcal {C} for the canonical \Sigma -structure that maps each variable to the appropriate product projection, each function symbol f\colon A_{1},\ldots ,A_{n}\to B to its underlying morphism f\colon A_{1} \times \cdots \times A_{n}\to B, and each relation symbol R \rightarrowtail A_{1},\ldots ,A_{n} to its underlying subobject R \rightarrowtail A_{1} \times \cdots \times A_{n}.

A category \mathcal {C} is said to be regular if it is cartesian, has images, and covers are stable under pullback. A functor F\colon \mathcal {C}\to \mathcal {D} between regular categories is said to be regular if it is cartesian and preserves covers. Note that since cartesian functors preserve monomorphisms, every regular functor automatically preserves images.

Let F\colon \mathcal {C}\to \mathcal {D} be a regular functor and f\colon A\to B be a morphism in \mathcal {C}. By , f admits a cover-mono factorization f = \mathsf {Img}(f)\vartheta _{f}. Then since F preserves monomorphisms and covers, F(\mathsf {Img}(f))F(\vartheta _{f}) forms a cover-mono factorization of F(f). Then by uniqueness, \mathsf {Img}(Ff) \cong F(\mathsf {Img}(f)).
